白宫官员周三表示，美国总统乔·拜登已开始使用持续气道正压通气机（CPAP）来解决睡眠呼吸暂停问题。

白宫发言人安德鲁·贝茨 (Andrew Bates) 表示：“他昨晚使用了 CPAP 呼吸机，这对于有这种病史的人来说很常见。”

一位不愿透露姓名的白宫官员表示，拜登最近几周开始使用持续正压呼吸机来改善睡眠质量。

白宫没有提供更多细节，说明哪些具体投诉或诊断促使使用该机器、之前如何治疗睡眠呼吸暂停，或者总统是否接受过睡眠研究。

此前并未披露该机器的使用情况，而且总统可能出现的任何呼吸暂停或睡眠问题也没有出现在二月份的总统健康状况摘要中，该摘要重点关注总统“目前正在接受治疗”的情况。

白宫表示，总统的健康状况是透明的，但没有说明为什么在机器启动时没有披露其用途。

拜登的医生凯文·奥康纳在拜登总统竞选团队发布的 2019 年报告中表示，他调查拜登是否患有睡眠呼吸暂停，但在鼻道和鼻窦手术后，他的症状有所改善。

睡眠呼吸暂停是一种常见疾病，其特征是睡眠期间呼吸短暂中断。

研究表明，如果不加以治疗，它会导致健忘、疲劳和嗜睡，并最终导致心血管疾病，因为它会给心脏带来巨大的压力。

周三，记者看到拜登脸上有痕迹，表明他戴着某种宽肩带。许多 CPAP 使用者都戴着用带子固定的面罩。彭博新闻首先报道了拜登使用该机器的情况。

现年 80 岁的拜登是美国历史上年龄最大的总统，他的年龄和健康状况一直是选民关注的焦点，因为他在 2024 年的大选中寻求第二个四年任期。年龄是增加患睡眠呼吸暂停风险的几个因素之一。

民意调查显示，大多数美国人对拜登的年龄表示担忧。

二月份，他的医生在体检后宣布他健康并且“适合执勤”。

该报告称，拜登“一生中大部分时间都在应对鼻窦充血”，并且“经过几次鼻窦和鼻道手术后，鼻窦症状有所改善”。

2008年，Politico在一篇有关拜登担任巴拉克·奥巴马副总统竞选搭档时发布的长达49页病史报告的报道中提到了拜登“反复出现的睡眠呼吸暂停问题”。

美国海岸警卫队表示，在导致船上五人死亡的内爆事故中，旅游潜水器的残骸与推测的人类遗骸一起被发现，并于周三被带上岸进行检查。

泰坦尼克号在潜入泰坦尼克号残骸时被毁坏的残骸，以及据信是人类遗骸的残骸，被加拿大船运至事故地点以北约 400 英里的加拿大纽芬兰圣约翰斯港口。据海岸警卫队称，悬挂北极地平线旗帜的船只。

该机构表示，这些证据将由海岸警卫队快艇运送到美国港口，由本周召开的海洋调查委员会进行分析和测试，以对泰坦号的失踪进行正式调查。

海岸警卫队的声明补充说，美国医疗专业人员还将“对在事故现场的残骸中仔细找到的假定人类遗骸进行正式分析”。

遗骸的性质和范围没有具体说明。

加拿大广播公司的视频显示，周三早上，起重机从“北极地平线”号的甲板上吊起了潜水器的机头和其他用白色防水布包裹的破碎碎片。

视频还显示，泰坦尼克号船体的碎片和带有悬垂电线的机器被从圣约翰号的船上取下，泰坦尼克号探险队就是在那里开始的。

6月18日，这艘22英尺长的泰坦号载着五人前往北大西洋百年沉船残骸，对碎片的检查预计将进一步揭示泰坦号发生灾难性内爆的原因。

加拿大运输安全委员会已展开自己的调查。

潜水器的碎片在两小时的潜水中大约一小时四十五分钟后与水面支撑船失去了联系，四天后人们在距泰坦尼克号沉船船头约 1,600 英尺（488 米）的海底发现了碎片。

一艘深海机器人潜水器在超过 2 英里的海底搜寻，这一发现结束了一场跨国搜寻，这场搜寻引起了全世界媒体的关注，并确定了船上五人的命运。

死者中包括潜水器飞行员斯托克顿·拉什 (Stockton Rush)，他是美国海洋之门探险公司 (OceanGate Expeditions) 的首席执行官，该公司拥有并运营泰坦号。同遇难者还有 58 岁的英国亿万富翁哈米什·哈丁 (Hamish Harding)； 48 岁的巴基斯坦出生商人 Shahzada Dawood 和他 19 岁的儿子 Suleman；和 77 岁的法国海洋学家保罗-亨利·纳尔若莱 (Paul-Henri Nargeolet)。

此次事故引发了人们对此类探险活动不受监管的性质以及 OceanGate 放弃对泰坦新颖设计进行第三方行业审查和认证的决定的质疑。

“我们的团队已经成功完成了海上作业，但仍在执行任务，并将于今天早上从北极地平线撤退，”运行用于回收碎片的机器人车辆的 Pelagic Research 在一份声明中表示。 。

伊斯梅尔·沙基尔 (Ismail Shakil) 在渥太华和史蒂夫·戈尔曼 (Steve Gorman) 在洛杉矶报道；由 Deepa Babington 和 Leslie Adler 编辑; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 00:02:28 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/pieces-shattered-titanic-submersible-brought-ashore-canada-2023-06-28/ https://www.reuters.com/world/pieces-shattered-titanic-submersible-brought-ashore-canada-2023-06-28/Ismail Shakil, Steve Gorman泰坦尼克号潜水/（更新 1，电视） Analysis: Where are Russia's top generals? Rumours swirl after mercenary mutinySummary:
  • 两名俄罗斯高级将军从公众视野中消失
  • 由于普京寻求重新确立权威，他们的命运尚不清楚
  • 雇佣兵老板要求国防部长免职
  • 然而谢尔盖·绍伊古本周已经多次露面
  • 逮捕、监禁一名将军的谣言四起

俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京(Vladimir Putin)力图重申其权威，且未经证实的报道称至少有一人被捕，在一场旨在推翻高层的雇佣军兵变失败后，俄罗斯最高级的将军们已经退出公众视野。

自从周六雇佣军首领叶夫根尼·普里戈任要求交出格拉西莫夫的兵变失败以来，俄罗斯最高将领瓦列里·格拉西莫夫就没有出现在公众场合或国家电视台上。自 6 月 9 日以来，国防部的新闻稿中也没有提及他。

一些西方军事分析人士称，67岁的格拉西莫夫是俄罗斯乌克兰战争的指挥官，也是俄罗斯三个“核公文包”之一的持有者。

也没有出现在视野中的还有俄罗斯媒体驻乌克兰副司令谢尔盖·苏罗维金将军，他因在叙利亚冲突中采取侵略性战术而被俄罗斯媒体称为“世界末日将军”。

《纽约时报》根据美国情报简报报道，周二称，他事先了解了这次叛乱，俄罗斯当局正在调查他是否是同谋。

克里姆林宫周三淡化了这份报告，称已经并将有很多猜测和八卦。

《莫斯科时报》俄语版和一位军事博主报道了苏罗维金被捕的消息，而其他一些在俄罗斯拥有大量追随者的军事记者表示，他和其他高级军官正在接受质询，询问他们在叛乱中可能扮演的角色。

路透社无法确定苏罗维金是否已被捕。

Rybar 是 Telegram 消息应用程序上一个有影响力的频道，由前俄罗斯国防部新闻官员运营，该频道表示正在进行清洗。

他说，当局正试图清除那些被认为在镇压叛乱方面“缺乏果断”的军事人员，因为一些报道称，部分武装部队似乎在叛乱初期没有采取任何行动来阻止瓦格纳武装分子。叛乱。

赖巴尔说：“瓦格纳私人军事公司的武装叛乱已成为对俄罗斯武装部队进行大规模清洗的借口。”

如果这一举动得到证实，可能会改变俄罗斯在乌克兰发动战争的方式——俄罗斯称之为“特别军事行动”——并在莫斯科试图阻止乌克兰反攻之际引发内部骚乱。

它还可以巩固或提升其他被视为忠诚的高级军事和安全人物的地位。

国防部没有对正在发生的事情发表正式评论。

赢家和输家

一些俄罗斯和西方军事和政治分析人士认为，国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古（Sergei Shoigu）是普京的老盟友，普里戈任因涉嫌无能而想与格拉西莫夫一起打倒，现在他的工作实际上可能更安全。

卡内基基金会智库俄罗斯军事专家迈克尔·科夫曼在推特上写道：“我认为他（普里戈任）实际上希望对绍伊古和格拉西莫夫采取一些措施，普京会做出对他有利的决定。”

“相反，他的叛变可能确保了他们的继续任职，尽管他被普遍认为是无能的，并且在俄罗斯联邦武装部队中受到普遍憎恶。”

曾任普京保镖的国民警卫队队长维克托·佐洛托夫似乎是另一个受益者，他在公开场合表示，他的士兵已准备好“誓死抵抗”，保卫莫斯科免受瓦格纳的侵害。

他谈到了在叛变后为他的部队获得重型武器和坦克的可能性。

当普京周二感谢军队避免了内战时，格拉西莫夫的缺席引人注目，而绍伊古此后多次公开露面。

格拉西莫夫的副手苏罗维金最后一次出现是在周六，当时他出现在一段视频中，呼吁普里戈任停止叛变。他看起来很疲惫，不清楚他是否是在胁迫下说话的。

周三晚上，未经证实的俄罗斯媒体和博主报道称，苏罗维金被捕后被关押在莫斯科的莱福托沃拘留所。

人脉广泛的记者阿列克谢·维内迪克托夫(Alexei Venediktov)在没有援引消息来源的情况下表示，苏罗维金自周六以来就没有与他的家人取得联系，他的保镖也保持沉默。

普里戈任几个月来一直在诽谤绍伊古和格拉西莫夫在乌克兰战争中的无能，但他经常赞扬苏罗维金，因为他在车臣和叙利亚的经历在军队中广受尊重。

苏罗维金在格拉西莫夫被任命接任之前曾担任乌克兰战争总司令，被西方军事分析家和部分乌克兰军方视为有效的操作者。

俄罗斯战地记者称他为未来潜在的国防部长。

  • 17岁少年在巴黎郊区被枪杀
  • 检察官展开凶杀案调查
  • 南泰尔汽车连续第二晚被烧毁

周三，巴黎工人阶级郊区南泰尔的抗议者向警察发射烟花，并纵火焚烧汽车，这是一名 17 岁男孩在交通站被枪杀后的第二个晚上的骚乱。

警察对这名北非裔青少年使用致命武力，在法国大城市的多种族郊区加深了人们对警察暴力行为的根深蒂固的看法。

午夜前不久，南泰尔巴勃罗毕加索大道上的警戒线上燃放烟花，一排翻倒的车辆被烧毁。

警方发言人表示，警方在北部城市里尔和西南部的图卢兹与抗议者发生冲突，亚眠、第戎和法国首都南部的埃松行政区也发生骚乱。

法国媒体报道了大巴黎地区许多其他地点发生的事件。社交媒体上的视频显示，巴黎东部边缘的蒙特勒伊市政厅燃放了数十枚烟花。

早些时候，总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙称枪击事件“无法解释且不可原谅”。

一名警察因射杀青少年而被指控故意杀人罪，目前正在接受调查。检察官称，他没有遵守停车命令。

内政部呼吁民众保持冷静，并表示巴黎地区已出动 2000 名警察。

人权组织指控法国执法机构内部存在系统性种族主义，马克龙此前否认了这一指控。

经路透社证实，社交媒体上分享的一段视频显示，这辆奔驰 AMG 车旁边有两名警察，其中一名警察在汽车开走时近距离向司机开枪。当地检察官称，他不久后因伤势过重而死亡。

“你有一段非常清晰的视频：一名警察杀死了一名 17 岁的年轻人。你可以看到枪击事件不符合规定，”该家庭的律师亚辛·布兹鲁 (Yassine Bouzrou) 说。

议员们在国民议会默哀一分钟，总理伊丽莎白·博恩表示，枪击事件“显然不符合规定”。

律师说，家人已对警官提出杀人、共谋杀人和虚假证言的法律申诉。

在 TikTok 上分享的一段视频中，一名被确认为受害者母亲的妇女周四呼吁在南泰尔举行纪念游行。 “大家都来，我们将为我的儿子领导一场叛乱，”她说。

异常坦率

法国国家警察发言人表示，周二的枪击事件是 2023 年迄今为止法国交通堵塞期间发生的第三起致命枪击事件，低于去年创纪录的 13 起。

据路透社统计，2021 年发生了三起此类杀戮事件，2020 年发生了两起，这表明自 2017 年以来大多数受害者是黑人或阿拉伯裔。

法国人权监察员已对这起死亡事件展开调查，这是 2022 年和 2023 年对类似事件进行的第六次调查。

考虑到选民的安全担忧，高级政客往往不愿批评警察，马克龙的言论异常坦率。

两个主要警察工会进行了反击，称被拘留的警察应该被推定为无罪，除非发现其他情况。

他面临着竞争对手的批评，他们指责他对毒贩和小罪犯态度软弱，并实施了旨在遏制城市犯罪的政策，包括赋予警察更大的罚款权力。

在暴力事件连续第二晚爆发之前，楠泰尔的一些人曾表示希望骚乱能够迅速结束。

当地居民法蒂玛说：“像我们昨天那样反抗不会改变事情，我们需要讨论和交谈。”

白金汉宫周四表示，飙升的通货膨胀已经打击了英国王室的财务，推高了支出，因为它透露查尔斯国王已下令关闭王室的供暖以减少排放。

年度主权拨款报告详细介绍了王室纳税人资助的支出和收入，其中详细说明了君主表示应将恒温器调低至 19 摄氏度（66.2°F）以减少温室气体排放，以符合他的长期目标环保运动。

迈克尔说：“您不需要我提醒您，在本报告所述期间，通货膨胀压力导致所有组织的许多商品和服务的价格大幅上涨，特别是在燃料和能源成本方面。”史蒂文斯，皇家财务主管。

去年是王室几代人以来最忙碌的一年，去年六月庆祝了伊丽莎白女王登基 70 周年，随后她于 9 月去世，查尔斯国王于 5 月加冕。

报道称，王室成员在女王葬礼和相关活动上花费了 160 万英镑（200 万美元）。英国政府5月份表示，估计总共花费了1.62亿英镑，其中包括治安和安保费用。

史蒂文斯说：“葬礼本身被认为是电视历史上观看现场直播活动中全球观众人数最多的。”史蒂文斯的官方头衔是“私人钱包守护者”。

本德特表示，根据俄罗斯公开消息来源，一架《柳叶刀》无人机的售价约为 300 万卢布（约合 35,000 美元）。

Because the Lancet is a single-use device that destroys itself on impact, Bendett said it can only be viable if the cost is kept down to the tens of thousands of dollars per drone.

DRONE WARS

Ukraine has also developed strong capabilities in drones - also known as UAVs (unmanned aerial vehicles) - as a cost-effective way to hit Russian targets.

Assault drones can send payloads to hit their target or serve as single-use "loitering munitions" - where they are strapped with explosives and ram the target themselves.

Bendett said there was unhappiness among pro-war Russian commentators about the large amount of Ukrainian videos showing successful UAV strikes, and that the Russian defence sector now wanted to create a competing narrative.

Russia appears to be copying some of Ukraine's earlier tactics, such as luring high-value targets forward into more exposed positions before hitting them with loitering munitions, Bendett said.

Yuriy Sak, an adviser to Ukraine's defence minister, acknowledged that Russia's increasing use of Lancets created difficulties.

"Every day we shoot down at least one or two of these Lancets ... but it's not a 100% interception rate unfortunately," he said.

Sak said the Lancet carried a relatively small explosive payload, ranging from 1.5-5 kg.

However, despite being less powerful than an artillery shell or most rockets, the Lancet appears to be able to inflict significant damage.

Lancet drones are flown in real-time by a pilot.

Sak said this distinguishes it from the Iran-made Shahed-136 drone, which Russia has also used extensively to hit Ukrainian targets, because a Shahed flies to a pre-programmed destination and cannot be piloted while in the air.

A NEAR MISS

The newest Lancet model, the Lancet 3, can fly up to 50 km (30 miles), Bendett said, making it better able to strike targets deep behind Ukrainian lines than any other Russian suicide drone besides the Shahed.

Its ability to loiter and then chase down its target makes it a threat to high-value equipment such as tanks, self-propelled artillery and rocket launch systems.

One of the Ukrainian vehicles most at risk is the BM-21 Grad, a large Soviet-era truck-mounted launcher that can fire a barrage of up to 40 rockets over a wide area.

Its firepower makes it a priority target for Lancet drones, and a video shared by pro-war Russian social media channels last week appeared to show a Grad being hit by a Lancet. Reuters could not independently verify the footage.

A crew member of a Grad launcher near Avdiivka, who introduced himself by his call sign Voron, recounted having a close brush with a Lancet which had been sent to attack his launcher in early May.

Having fired on a Russian target, Voron said his Grad was immediately targeted by a Russian S-300 missile, which missed by about 150 metres. However, a Lancet drone then appeared in the sky and chased the Ukrainian rocket system.

"We decided to flee ... After about 50 metres it fell just to my right. It didn't hit us, thank God," the 27-year-old said.

Drones like the Lancet, which fly low and slow, tend to confuse traditional air defence systems, which are built to intercept fast-moving targets with a larger heat signature.

Nets or metal cages can help limit the damage, said Sak, the defence ministry official, but the best defences are radar-equipped automated anti-drone guns, as well as electronic warfare systems.

Sak said Ukraine needed many more of these systems from its allies.

Without such systems, Ukrainian soldiers are often forced to try to shoot the Lancets down with small arms.

"It's flying at 100 kilometres per hour, so shooting it down with small arms is not an easy challenge," said Sak.

  • Fears of civil war rose in world's biggest nuclear power
  • Mercenaries posed biggest threat to Putin in 23-year rule
  • 'Anyone with anything to lose was extremely tense' -source
  • The elite wonder: What's next for Russia?

As one of the most brutal mercenary forces marched on Moscow, some among Russia's elite trembled in fear that the world's biggest nuclear power was teetering on the brink of what President Vladimir Putin said could have been a civil war.

With Putin facing the biggest public challenge of his 23 years as paramount leader, some private jets sped out of Moscow, according to flight tracking data and one source with knowledge of the matter.

One fear was that Yevgeny Prigozhin's Wagner mercenary group, if he entered Moscow, would try to take over the economy, triggering yet another redistribution of ownership in Russia, the world's biggest supplier of natural resources.

When Prigozhin's men turned back just over 200 km (150 miles) from Moscow, a different fear set in: that Putin, furious in his humiliation, would tighten the screws even further and take revenge against those considered not sufficiently loyal.

"A new reality has dawned in Russia," a senior Russian source told Reuters on condition of anonymity when asked what had happened.

"And why do you use the past tense? What foundation do you have to say that anything has finished?" said the source. "The events of Saturday have shown that armed men can at any moment bend the whole country to their will."

Another senior source in Moscow, who requested anonymity, said fear triumphed in the tumultuous hours of Saturday and that many rushed to make plans to get their families out of Moscow.

That source said that it was clear that Putin's authority had been damaged but that it was far too early to make any sweeping conclusions from events which the source said did not appear to make full sense.

"The speed and gravity of whatever this was has completely shocked everyone, including in the Kremlin," the source said.

In interviews with Reuters, about a dozen members of the Russian elite related their jitters as the mutiny unfolded, the biggest internal challenge to the Russian state since the 1991 coup bid against Mikhail Gorbachev as the Soviet Union crumbled.

Their trepidation and reactions give an insight into the depths of the fissures inside Putin's Russia after 16 months of war in Ukraine that shows no sign of ending any time soon.

"Anyone with anything to lose was extremely tense," said a source with knowledge of the thinking at the top levels of the Russian business and political elites, which often overlap.

TURMOIL

As the mutiny unfolded, Putin, who has dominated Russia since the last day of 1999, gave an address to the nation at 10 am Moscow time from the Kremlin on June 24 vowing to crush the mutiny and warning that Russia could tip towards turmoil.

The former KGB spy used the dreaded Russian word "smuta" which means unrest, turmoil or trouble and is associated in Russian minds with the so-called "time of troubles" which preceded the rise of the Romanov dynasty in 1613.

Putin said the armed mutiny was treason and compared it to the chaos that ushered in the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917 and then years of civil war.

As Putin spoke, the rouble was tumbling towards 100 per US dollar for those lucky enough to be able to find dollars to buy. The rouble was trading at 84 per US dollar on Thursday. It is currently trading at around 86 per dollar.

Russians started to withdraw significant amounts of roubles and seek foreign currency in 15 regions across Russia.

On average the demand for foreign currency and cash rose about 30% but in southern regions near the mutiny and in large cities, demand rocketed up by 70-80%, according to an update by First Deputy Prime Minister Andrei Belousov.

Air ticket prices from Moscow were also soaring for trips to destinations such as Belgrade, Istanbul and Dubai.

Tickets for direct flights to Belgrade sold out. One-way tickets to Belgrade via Sochi soared in price to 63,700 roubles ($742). Tickets to Istanbul quadrupled in price.

Jets linked to at least two major business figures and at least one senior government official flew out of Moscow on June 24, according to flight tracking data. Reuters was unable to determine who flew out on the jets.

Russian parliamentary deputy Dmitry Gusev has written to Russia's air transport agency demanding that it publish the names of famous businessmen and politicians who flew out of Russia on June 24.

'HEADS WILL ROLL'

Just hours later a deal was clinched to allow Prigozhin and some of his fighters to go to neighbouring Belarus.

Russia had, it seemed, stared into the abyss.

Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko used criminal slang to say he had persuaded Putin on Saturday not to "wipe out" Prigozhin, who flew to Belarus on Tuesday.

Prigozhin said he never intended to overthrow Russia's leaders but had marched to save his group and settle scores with Putin's top military brass, Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and the Chief of General Staff, Valery Gerasimov.

Prigozhin, though, boasted about the speed of the march of his men towards Moscow, covering 780 km in just one day, saying it showed the extent of the security problems in Russia.

Viktor Zolotov, a close Putin ally and director of the National Guard, said that the mutineers were able to advance so fast towards Moscow because forces loyal to the state had focused on bolstering the defences of the capital.

Zolotov, who served as head of the presidential bodyguard from 2000 to 2013 and was sometimes seen carrying an automatic weapon to protect Putin on dangerous trips, said his men would have stood to the death.

But within the elite, there is now a fear that Putin will seek to assert his position and remove those he felt did not profess their loyalty with enough ardour.

"Heads will roll," said another senior source. "They will look at who kept silent, who did not speak in support of unity and of the president."

Reporting by Guy Faulconbridge; Editing by Mark Heinrich and Daniel Wallis ; Wed, 28 Jun 2023 19:51:13 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-teetered-elite-trembled-some-private-jets-left-2023-06-28/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-teetered-elite-trembled-some-private-jets-left-2023-06-28/Guy Faulconbridge, Darya Korsunskaya, Gleb Stolyarov乌克兰CRISIS/RUSSIA ELITE (UPDATE 1, PIX) For Ketanji Brown Jackson, a self-assured and forceful US Supreme Court debut

In December, during a heated US Supreme Court oral argument involving a collision between free speech protections for business owners and LGBT rights, liberal Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, who had joined the bench only about two months before, raised the most memorable question of the day.

Jackson, the first Black woman to serve on the top US juridical body, suggested to a lawyer for Lorie Smith , a Christian web designer from Colorado seeking a right to refuse to design websites for same-sex marriages, that the case could be a slippery slope.

A win for Smith, Jackson said, could allow a professional photographer to exclude Black children from a nostalgic Christmas photo with Santa Claus styled after the 1940s - a time of racial segregation in parts of the United States - because "they're trying to capture the feelings of a certain era," Jackson said.

After pressing the example, Kristen Waggoner, Smith's attorney, responded that "there are difficult lines to draw and that may be an edge case."

As the court's current term nears its end, Jackson, appointed by Democratic President Joe Biden last year, has earned a reputation as an assertive presence with a bit of an independent streak, willing to ask tough questions and to decide cases with her fellow liberals or at times with the majority conservatives.

According to legal scholar Adam Feldman, who tracks court data, Jackson spoke more during oral arguments than any of the other current justices during their first terms.

"She's just showed up from day one," said Terry Maroney, a Vanderbilt Law School professor who studies judicial decision-making and behavior. "She knows what she's doing, she's not shy, she's posing uncomfortable hypotheticals - and she's not afraid to do those things even if it's causing discomfort."

Some of the major cases have yet to be decided - including Smith's case and the fate of race-conscious university student admissions policies that for decades have boosted the number of underrepresented minorities on American campuses - with more rulings expected on Thursday.

The addition of Jackson, a former federal trial and appellate court judge, did not change the ideological make-up of the court, whose muscular 6-3 conservative majority has shown a willingness to rapidly change the law. Jackson succeeded fellow liberal Justice Stephen Breyer .

Last year, rulings powered by the conservative justices ended recognition of a constitutional right to abortion and widened gun rights. This term, they ruled against the Environmental Protection Agency in a case that could leave wide swathes of sensitive wetlands unprotected by a landmark anti-pollution law.

The term also has included several rulings that surprised scholars and court watchers, with conservative justices joining the liberals in rejecting race-based challenges to a federal voting rights law that protects minorities and an adoption law governing Native American children.

'VERY SELF-AWARE'

Boston College constitutional law expert Kent Greenfield said Jackson's presence on the bench may have helped shape those rulings in part by bringing a different life experience to the table.

"She's a person of heft, a person of high intellect and she's not being quiet," Greenfield said. "She's very self-aware of the role she's playing."

Some of her questions during oral arguments have stood out.

In one of the cases challenging affirmative action policies in collegiate admissions, Jackson suggested that barring any consideration of race could prevent a student who descends from slaves, compared to one who is not, from having his family history honored and credited "because his story is in many ways bound up with his race and with the race of his ancestors."

"My sense is she will have a disproportionate amount of influence over her colleagues, especially with the question of race," Greenfield said.

Jackson has voted alongside fellow liberal Justices Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan in several cases, but also has diverged from them including in May when she dissented from a decision backing an animal-welfare law in California, and last week when she joined a ruling making it easier to deport immigrants convicted of certain crimes.

Roman Martinez, a former law clerk for conservative Chief Justice John Roberts who frequently argues cases at the court, said Jackson's first term has been impressive, calling her very active and extremely prepared.

"She has also shown an independent streak, willing to break from the more liberal wing of the court and articulate her own views in solo opinions or by teaming up" with conservative Justice Neil Gorsuch, Martinez said.

As the first former public defender ever to serve on the Supreme Court, Jackson has distinguished herself in her handling of criminal justice matters, authoring at least seven pro-defendant dissenting opinions this term in argued cases, appeal denials and emergency applications.

"She's made her personality and priorities and intellect known very quickly on the bench this year," Maroney said.

美国东亚事务高级外交官丹尼尔·克里滕布林克 (Daniel Kritenbrink) 周三表示，美国和中国同意考虑扩大两国之间的商业航班，以改善人员往来。

他在华盛顿举行的战略与国际研究中心智库活动中表示，两国同意“考虑分阶段增加美国和中国之间的商业航班数量”。

Kritenbrink 表示，在新冠病毒爆发之前，美国和中国之间每周约有 350 趟航班，而目前每周有 24 趟航班。

“我认为我们可以做得更好，”他补充道。

他说，该协议是在本月早些时候国务卿安东尼·布林肯访华期间达成的。访问期间，华盛顿和北京的竞争未能取得任何重大突破，但同意稳定关系。布林肯此行后不久，美国总统乔·拜登将中国国家主席习近平称为独裁者。

2020年COVID-19大流行开始后，两国限制航班和旅行以防止疾病传播，航空服务尚未完全恢复。

克里滕布林克表示，他希望看到中国在美学生和美国在华学生人数的不平衡状况得到扭转，他预计中国学生为30万名，美国学生为350名。

在周三的活动中，克里滕布林克将中国在南海的行为描述为胁迫性的。
